item.title: Declarations
item.dc:creator: @xx_qwertyuiop_xx xx qwertyuiop xx
item.description:
@xx_qwertyuiop_xx wrote:

Since you’ve named the variable isInArea it needs to be called as isInArea.

if(c.isInArea(objectX - 2, objectX + 2, objectY - 2, objectY + 2))

Sorry, I accidentally made the method static. Remove the static modifier.

[quote=“ollie123, post:32, topic:266086”]Ok. Make sure that you change c.isInArea2 to c.isInArea
And make sure that the isInArea method is not static.[/quote]
You keep answering before me, lol.

Read full topic

item.title: Declarations
item.dc:creator: @ollie123 Ollie123
item.description:
@ollie123 wrote:

Ok. Make sure that you change c.isInArea2 to c.isInArea
And make sure that the isInArea method is not static.

Read full topic

item.title: Declarations
item.dc:creator: @xx_qwertyuiop_xx xx qwertyuiop xx
item.description:
@xx_qwertyuiop_xx wrote:

[quote=“Setsuna, post:23, topic:266086”]So…What…Like…

public static boolean isInArea2; //In area 2…?

Confused still…[/quote]

Yes, but it’s not a variable. It’s a method that returns a boolean.
It would probably look something like this:

public boolean isInArea(int westX, int eastX, int southY, int northY) // There really isn't a reason to call it isInArea2, just isInArea.
{
    return absX >= westX && absX <= eastX && absY >= southY && absY <= northY;
}

Read full topic
